panels.title: Timeseries - Folder Sizes - Monitoring DBs & Plex [Docker Containers]

panels.description: How many entries inverted index contains. This value is proportional to the number of unique timeseries in storage(cardinality).
panels.title: Index size

panels.description: Total size of allowed memory via flag `-memory.allowedPercent`
panels.title: Allowed memory

panels.description: Average disk usage per datapoint.
panels.title: Bytes per point

panels.description: Total amount of used disk space
panels.title: Disk space usage

panels.description: How many datapoints are in storage
panels.title: Total datapoints

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests rate

panels.description:
The less time it takes is better.
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Query duration

panels.description:
Shows the number of active time series with new data points inserted during the last hour. High value may result in ingestion slowdown. 

See following link for details:
panels.title: Active time series

panels.description:
* `*` - unsupported query path
* `/write` - insert into VM
* `/metrics` - query VM system metrics
* `/query` - query instant values
* `/query_range` - query over a range of time
* `/series` - match a certain label set
* `/label/{}/values` - query a list of label values (variables mostly)
panels.title: Requests error rate

panels.description:
Shows how many ongoing insertions (not API /write calls) on disk are taking place, where:
* `max` - equal to number of CPUs;
* `current` - current number of goroutines busy with inserting rows into underlying storage.

Every successful API /write call results into flush on disk. However, these two actions are separated and controlled via different concurrency limiters. The `max` on this panel can't be changed and always equal to number of CPUs. 

When `current` hits `max` constantly, it means storage is overloaded and requires more CPU.
panels.title: Concurrent flushes on disk

panels.description: Cache hit ratio shows cache efficiency. The higher is hit rate the better.
panels.title: Cache hit ratio

panels.description: VictoriaMetrics stores various caches in RAM. Memory size for these caches may be limited with -`memory.allowedPercent` flag. Line `max allowed` shows max allowed memory size for cache.
panels.title: Cache size

panels.description: How many datapoints are inserted into storage per second
panels.title: Datapoints ingestion rate

targets.expr: vm_free_disk_space_bytes{job=~"victoria-metrics", instance=~"self"} / ignoring(path) ((rate(vm_rows_added_to_storage_total{job=~"victoria-metrics", instance=~"self"}[1d]) - ignoring(type) rate(vm_deduplicated_samples_total{job=~"victoria-metrics", instance=~"self", type="merge"}[1d])) * scalar(sum(vm_data_size_bytes{job=~"victoria-metrics", instance=~"self", type!="indexdb"}) / sum(vm_rows{job=~"victoria-metrics", instance=~"self", type!="indexdb"})))

panels.title: Storage full ETA

panels.description: Shows how many datapoints are in the storage and what is average disk usage per datapoint.
panels.title: Datapoints

panels.description: How many datapoints are in RAM queue waiting to be written into storage. The number of pending data points should be in the range from 0 to `2*<ingestion_rate>`, since VictoriaMetrics pushes pending data to persistent storage every second.
panels.title: Pending datapoints

panels.description: Shows amount of on-disk space occupied by data points and the remaining disk space at `-storageDataPath`
panels.title: Disk space usage - datapoints

panels.description:
Data parts of LSM tree.
High number of parts could be an evidence of slow merge performance - check the resource utilization.
* `indexdb` - inverted index
* `storage/small` - recently added parts of data ingested into storage(hot data)
* `storage/big` -  small parts gradually merged into big parts (cold data)
panels.title: LSM parts

panels.description: Shows amount of on-disk space occupied by inverted index.
panels.title: Disk space usage - index

panels.description: The number of on-going merges in storage nodes.  It is expected to have high numbers for `storage/small` metric.
panels.title: Active merges

panels.description: Shows how many rows were ignored on insertion due to corrupted or out of retention timestamps.
panels.title: Rows ignored

panels.description: The number of rows merged per second by storage nodes.
panels.title: Merge speed

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

panels.description:
Shows the rate and total number of new series created over last 24h.

High churn rate tightly connected with database performance and may result in unexpected OOM's or slow queries. It is recommended to always keep an eye on this metric to avoid unexpected cardinality "explosions".

The higher churn rate is, the more resources required to handle it. Consider to keep the churn rate as low as possible.

Good references to read:
* https://www.robustperception.io/cardinality-is-key
* https://www.robustperception.io/using-tsdb-analyze-to-investigate-churn-and-cardinality
panels.title: Churn rate

panels.description: Shows the rate of adding new items to the index. It should correlate with `Slow inserts` and `Churn rate` graphs and could help to determine the pressure on indexdb.
panels.title: IndexDB items rate

panels.description:
The percentage of slow inserts comparing to total insertion rate during the last 5 minutes. 

The less value is better. If percentage remains high (>10%) during extended periods of time, then it is likely more RAM is needed for optimal handling of the current number of active time series. 

In general, VictoriaMetrics requires ~1KB or RAM per active time series, so it should be easy calculating the required amounts of RAM for the current workload according to capacity planning docs. But the resulting number may be far from the real number because the required amounts of memory depends on may other factors such as the number of labels per time series and the length of label values.
panels.title: Slow inserts

panels.description: Slow queries rate according to `search.logSlowQueryDuration` flag, which is `5s` by default.
panels.title: Slow queries rate

panels.description:
Shows the percentage of used cache size from the allowed size by type. 
Values close to 100% show the maximum potential utilization.
Values close to 0% show that cache is underutilized.
panels.title: Cache usage %

panels.description:
VictoriaMetrics limits the number of labels per each metric with `-maxLabelsPerTimeseries` command-line flag.

This prevents from ingesting metrics with too many labels. The value of `maxLabelsPerTimeseries` must be adjusted for your workload.

When limit is exceeded (graph is > 0) - extra labels are dropped, which could result in unexpected identical time series.
panels.title: Labels limit exceeded

panels.description:
Panel shows the number of open file descriptors in the OS.
Reaching the limit of open files can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs

panels.description: Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer.
panels.title: Disk writes/reads

panels.description: Shows avg GC duration
panels.title: GC duration

panels.description:
Shows total number of all configured scrape targets in state "up".

See `http://vmagent-host:8429/targets` to get list of all targets.
panels.title: Uptime

panels.description:
Shows total number of all configured scrape targets in state "up".

See `http://vmagent-host:8429/targets` to get list of all targets.
panels.title: Scrape targets up

panels.description:
Shows total number of all configured scrape targets in state "down".

See `http://vmagent-host:8429/targets` to get list of all targets.
panels.title: Scrape targets down

panels.description: Shows number of generated  error messages in  logs over last 30m. Non-zero value may be a sign of connectivity or missconfiguration errors.
panels.title: Log errors (30m)

panels.description:
Persistent queue size shows size of pending samples in bytes which hasn't been flushed to remote storage yet. 
Increasing of value might be a sign of connectivity issues. In such cases, vmagent starts to flush pending data on disk with attempt to send it later once connection is restored.
panels.title: Persistent queue size

panels.description:
Shows in/out samples rate including push and pull models. 

The out-rate could be different to in-rate because of replication or additional timeseries added by vmagent for every scraped target.
panels.title: Samples rate

panels.description: Shows the rate of requests served by vmagent HTTP server.
panels.title: Requests rate

panels.description: Errors rate shows rate for multiple metrics that track possible errors in vmagent, such as network or parsing errors.
panels.title: Errors rate

panels.description:
Shows the persistent queue size of pending samples in bytes which hasn't been flushed to remote storage yet. 

Increasing of value might be a sign of connectivity issues. In such cases, vmagent starts to flush pending data on disk with attempt to send it later once connection is restored.

Remote write URLs are hidden by default but might be unveiled once `-remoteWrite.showURL` is set to true.
panels.title: Persistent queue size

panels.description:
Shows the rate of dropped data blocks in cases when remote storage replies with `400 Bad Request` and `409 Conflict` HTTP responses.

See https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/1149
panels.title: Data blocks dropped

panels.description:
Shows rate of dropped samples from persistent queue. VMagent drops samples from queue if in-memory and on-disk queues are full and it is unable to flush them to remote storage.
The max size of on-disk queue is configured by `-remoteWrite.maxDiskUsagePerURL` flag.
panels.title: Persistent queue dropped rate

panels.description:
Shows the rate of dropped samples due to relabeling. 
Metric tracks drops for `-remoteWrite.relabelConfig` configuration only.
panels.title: Rows dropped by relabeling

panels.description: Shows the rate of logging the messages by their level. Unexpected spike in rate is a good reason to check logs.
panels.title: Logging rate

panels.description: This panel uses MetricsQL and works only when VM is used as a datasource
panels.title: Scrape duration

panels.description: Shows the rate of write requests served by ingestserver (UDP, TCP connections) and HTTP server.
panels.title: Requests rate

panels.description: Shows the rate of write errors in ingestserver (UDP, TCP connections) and HTTP server.
panels.title: Error rate

panels.description: Shows the rate of parsed rows from write or scrape requests.
panels.title: Rows rate

panels.description: Tracks the rate of dropped invalid rows because of errors while unmarshaling write requests. The exact errors messages will be printed in logs.
panels.title: Invalid rows rate

panels.description:
Shows the rate of requests to configured remote write endpoints by url and status code.

Remote write URLs are hidden by default but might be unveiled once `-remoteWrite.showURL` is set to true.
panels.title: Requests rate

panels.description: Shows the global rate for number of written bytes via remote write connections.
panels.title: Bytes write rate

panels.description:
Shows requests retry rate by url. Number of retries is unlimited but protected with delays up to 1m between attempts.

Remote write URLs are hidden by default but might be unveiled once `-remoteWrite.showURL` is set to true.
panels.title: Retry rate

panels.description: Shows current number of established connections to remote write endpoints.
panels.title: Connections

panels.description: Shows the remote write request duration distribution in seconds. Value depends on block size, network quality and remote storage performance.
panels.title: Push duration

panels.description: Shows saturation of every connection to remote storage. If the threshold of 0.9sec is reached, then the connection is saturated by more than 90% and vmagent won't be able to keep up. This usually means that `-remoteWrite.queues` command-line flag must be increased in order to increase the number of connections per each remote storage.
panels.title: Remote write connection saturation

panels.description: Shows the remote write request block size distribution in rows.
panels.title: Block size rows

panels.description: Shows the remote write request block size distribution in bytes.
panels.title: Block size bytes

panels.description:
Shows the current limit usage of unique series over an hourly period. Vmagent will start to drop series once the limit is reached.

Please note, panel will be blank if `remoteWrite.maxHourlySeries` is not set.
panels.title: Hourly series limit

panels.description:
Shows the current limit usage of unique series over a daily period. Vmagent will start to drop series once the limit is reached.

Please note, panel will be blank if `remoteWrite.maxDailySeries` is not set.
panels.title: Daily series limit

panels.description: Shows top 5 job by the number of new series registered by vmagent over the 5min range. These jobs generate the most of the churn rate.
panels.title: Top 5 jobs by unique samples

panels.description: Shows top 5 instances by the number of new series registered by vmagent over the 5min range. These instances generate the most of the churn rate.
panels.title: Top 5 instances by unique samples

panels.description: Shows saturation persistent queue for writes. If the threshold of 0.9sec is reached, then persistent is saturated by more than 90% and vmagent won't be able to keep up with flushing data on disk. In this case, consider to decrease load on the vmagent or improve the disk throughput.
panels.title: Persistent queue write saturation

panels.description: Shows saturation persistent queue for reads. If the threshold of 0.9sec is reached, then persistent is saturated by more than 90% and vmagent won't be able to keep up with reading data from the disk. In this case, consider to decrease load on the vmagent or improve the disk throughput.
panels.title: Persistent queue read saturation

panels.description:
Shows the CPU usage per vmagent instance. 
If you think that usage is abnormal or unexpected pls file an issue and attach CPU profile if possible.
panels.title: CPU

panels.description:
Amount of used memory

If you think that usage is abnormal or unexpected, please file an issue and attach memory profile if possible.
panels.title: Memory usage

panels.description: Shows the number of bytes read/write from the storage layer when vmagent has to buffer data on disk or read already buffered data.
panels.title: Disk writes/reads

panels.description:
Network usage shows the bytes rate for data accepted by vmagent and pushed via remotewrite protocol.
Discrepancies are possible because of different protocols used for ingesting, scraping and writing data.
panels.title: Network  usage

panels.description:
Panel shows the number of open file descriptors in the OS.
Reaching the limit of open files can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs

panels.description: Displays the number of HTTP requests per minute.
panels.title: Active Queries

panels.description: Displays the current heap size.

targets.query: SELECT moving_average(mean("HeapSys"), 10) AS "heap sys", moving_average(mean("HeapInUse"), 10) AS "heap active", moving_average(mean("HeapIdle"), 10) AS "heap idle" FROM "monitor"."runtime" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "hostname" fill(none)

panels.title: Heap Usage

panels.description: Displays the current GC activity.

targets.query: SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean("PauseTotalNs"),1s) AS "mean_PauseTotalNs" FROM "monitor"."runtime" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "hostname" fill(none)

panels.title: GC Activity

panels.description: Displays the number of HTTP requests per minute.

targets.query: SELECT non_negative_derivative(mean("queryReq"), 1m) FROM "monitor"."httpd" WHERE ("hostname" =~ /^$hostname$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($Interval), "hostname" fill(null)

panels.title: HTTP Requests / Minute

panels.description: Displays the number of HTTP errors per minute.
panels.title: HTTP Errors / Minute

panels.description: Displays the duration, in nanoseconds, of the top 1% of HTTP requests.

targets.query:
SELECT non_negative_derivative(percentile("writeReqDurationNs", 99)) / non_negative_derivative(max("writeReq")) AS "Write Request"
FROM "monitor"."httpd" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "hostname" fill(null)

SELECT non_negative_derivative(percentile("queryReqDurationNs", 99)) / non_negative_derivative(max("queryReq")) AS "Query Request"
FROM "monitor"."httpd" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "hostname" fill(null)

panels.title: HTTP Request Duration (99th %)

panels.description: Displays the duration, in nanoseconds, of the top 1% of HTTP WRITE requests.

targets.query:
SELECT non_negative_derivative(percentile("writeReqDurationNs", 99)) / non_negative_derivative(max("writeReq")) AS "Write Request"
FROM "monitor"."httpd" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "hostname" fill(null)

panels.title: HTTP Write Request Duration (99th %)

panels.description: Displays the duration, in nanoseconds, of the top 1% of HTTP READ requests.

targets.query:
SELECT non_negative_derivative(percentile("queryReqDurationNs", 99)) / non_negative_derivative(max("queryReq")) AS "Query Request"
FROM "monitor"."httpd" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "hostname" fill(null)

panels.title: HTTP Read Request Duration (99th %)

panels.description: Displays the number of measurements, by database.
panels.title: Number of Measurements by Database

panels.description: Displays the number of series (series cardinality) for the specified databases.
panels.title: Series Cardinality by Database

panels.description: Displays the number of shard write errors.
panels.title: Shard Write Errors

panels.description: Displays the number of queries executed per minute.
panels.title: Queries Executed / Minute

panels.description: Displays the non-negative mean rate of change in continuous queries (CQs) executed per minute.
panels.title: Continuous Queries Executed / Minute

panels.description: Displays the number of points requested each minute, by hostname.
panels.title: Point Throughput / Minute by Hostname

targets.query: SELECT non_negative_derivative(last("pointsWrittenFail"), 1m) FROM "httpd" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "host" fill(null)
SELECT non_negative_derivative(last("pointsWrittenOK"), 1m) FROM "httpd" WHERE $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval), "host" fill(null)

panels.title: Prometheus Metric & Target Uptime (obsolete with VicMetrics)
